senses.ex: My house is adjacent to the supermarket.

Tips.title: Physical Proximity
Tips.description: Use 'adjacent' to describe things side by side, touching or very close.
Tips.example: The pool is adjacent to the hotel.

Tips.title: Not Direct Access
Tips.description: 'Adjacent' implies closeness but not necessarily a direct entrance from one to another.
Tips.example: The parking lot is adjacent to the building, but you have to walk around to enter.

senses.de: Having a common point or border with something
senses.ex: The two states are adjacent to each other, they share the same border.

Tips.title: Common Boundary
Tips.description: 'Adjacent' can also mean sharing a boundary or border, not just being close.
Tips.example: Canada and the United States have adjacent national parks.

Tips.title: Geographical Context
Tips.description: In geography, 'adjacent' often refers to areas of land or countries.
Tips.example: Alaska is adjacent to the Yukon Territory of Canada.

senses.de: In mathematics, having a side or vertex in common with
senses.ex: In a square, all four sides are adjacent to each other.

Tips.title: Geometry Usage
Tips.description: In geometry, 'adjacent' refers to sides or angles that meet or connect.
Tips.example: Adjacent angles together make a straight line.

Tips.title: Shared Vertex
Tips.description: Shapes with a common corner point are 'adjacent' in mathematics.
Tips.example: Two triangles are adjacent if they share a common vertex.

senses.de: In graphs theory, having a direct connection or path
senses.ex: In a graph, two nodes are considered adjacent if there is a direct edge connecting them.

Tips.title: Graph Theory
Tips.description: In computer science, 'adjacent' describes nodes with a direct link in a network.
Tips.example: If a computer is adjacent to a server, they can communicate directly.

Tips.title: Direct Connections
Tips.description: 'Adjacent' infers a one-step relationship in network or graph theory.
Tips.example: Data can be quickly transferred between adjacent devices.

Abut.wordDefinition:
Abut means to touch or be next to something, usually at the edge or boundary. For example, two houses may abut each other or a park may abut a residential area.

The main difference between abut and adjacent is that abut implies physical contact, while adjacent implies proximity without contact.

Adjoin.wordDefinition:
Adjoin means to be next to or touching something.

However, it is often used to describe two things that are connected or share a boundary. For example, two pieces of land that share a border are said to adjoin each other.

The main difference is that adjacent describes things that are next to each other, while adjoin describes things that are connected or share a boundary.

Border.wordDefinition:
Border means the edge or boundary of something. For example, the border between two countries or states is the line that separates them.

Adjacent refers to things that are physically next to each other, while border refers to the line or boundary between two things.

Close.wordDefinition:
Adjacent means next to or adjoining something, while the word close means near or in proximity to something.

On the other hand, two buildings could be considered close if they are nearby each other, but not necessarily touching, such as in a neighborhood where houses are spaced out.

Adjacent refers specifically to something that is right next to or touching another thing, while close refers more generally to something that is near or in proximity to another thing.

Connect.wordDefinition:
Connect means to join or link something together. For example, a bridge connects two sides of a river, or a person can connect two hoses together to increase the range of their watering.

Adjacent describes something's position relative to another thing, while connect describes when two things are joined or linked together.

Contiguous.wordDefinition:
The words adjacent and contiguous both mean close together, but they can have slightly different meanings depending on the context.

Contiguous means sharing a common boundary or touching each other, without any separation or gap. For example, a field and a forest can be contiguous, meaning they share a common boundary without any space in between.

Adjacent is applicable when there is a clear separation or boundary between two things that are close together, while contiguous is applicable when two things share a common boundary or touch each other without any separation.

Neighbouring.wordDefinition:
The words adjacent and neighbouring both describe something that is close to another thing, but there is a slight difference in their use.

Neighbouring, however, can describe things that are near each other, but not necessarily directly next to each other.

For example, your house may have neighbouring houses on either side, but there may be a few meters of space between them.

Adjacent means things that are directly next to each other, while neighbouring means things that are close by but not necessarily touching.

Proximate.wordDefinition:
Proximate means things that are near or close to each other in proximity, whether or not they are physically touching.

For example, two houses that are across the street from each other could be described as proximate.
